name: Eiffel Tower
clues: I was built for a World's Fair in 1889
I was once the tallest man-made structure in the world
I'm made of iron and was initially criticized by many Parisians
funFacts: The Eiffel Tower was supposed to be a temporary installation, intended to stand for 20 years before being dismantled
It takes 20,000 light bulbs to make the tower sparkle at night
The Eiffel Tower grows in summer! Due to thermal expansion, the tower can be up to 15 cm taller in summer than in winter

name: Machu Picchu
clues: I'm an ancient Incan citadel set high in the Andes Mountains
I was built in the 15th century and later abandoned
I was unknown to the outside world until 1911
funFacts: Machu Picchu was built without the use of wheels, iron tools, or mortar
The site is precisely aligned with astronomical events like the winter solstice
Many of the stones used in construction weigh more than 50 tons and were somehow transported up the mountain

name: Great Wall of China
clues: I stretch over 13,000 miles across northern China
I was built to protect against nomadic invasions
Construction on me began more than 2,000 years ago
funFacts: Contrary to popular belief, the Great Wall cannot be seen from the moon with the naked eye
The mortar used to bind the stones includes sticky rice
It's estimated that up to 1 million people died during the wall's construction

name: Taj Mahal
clues: I was built as a tomb for an emperor's favorite wife
My construction took over 20 years and 20,000 workers
I'm made of white marble that changes color throughout the day
funFacts: The Taj Mahal's four minarets (towers) were designed to lean slightly outward so that in case of collapse, they would fall away from the main structure
The precious stones used in the inlay work were sourced from all over Asia
During World War II, the Taj Mahal was covered with scaffolding to disguise it from enemy bombers

name: Colosseum
clues: I could hold up to 80,000 spectators in ancient times
I was used for gladiatorial contests and public spectacles
My construction began around 70-72 CE and was completed in 80 CE
funFacts: The Colosseum had a complex system of elevators and trapdoors that could quickly bring animals, gladiators, or scenery into the arena
It's estimated that over 500,000 people and over a million wild animals died in the Colosseum games
The Colosseum was originally covered with a massive canvas awning to protect spectators from the sun

name: Statue of Liberty
clues: I was a gift from France to the United States
I hold a torch in my right hand and a tablet in my left
My full name is 'Liberty Enlightening the World'
funFacts: The Statue of Liberty's face was modeled after the sculptor's mother
The seven spikes on her crown represent the seven continents and seas
The statue was delivered to the United States in 350 individual pieces packed in 214 crates

name: Petra
clues: I'm an ancient city carved into rose-colored stone cliffs
I was established as early as 312 BCE as the capital of the Nabataean Kingdom
I was rediscovered in 1812 after being lost to the Western world
funFacts: Petra's most famous structure, the Treasury, was featured in 'Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade'
The city's sophisticated water system allowed the Nabataeans to create an artificial oasis in the desert
Only about 15% of the ancient city has been uncovered; the rest remains underground

name: Sydney Opera House
clues: My distinctive sail-shaped shells make me instantly recognizable
I was designed by Danish architect JÃ¸rn Utzon
My construction took 14 years and was completed in 1973
funFacts: The Sydney Opera House's construction cost 14 times the original budget
The roof is covered with over 1 million tiles that are self-cleaning
The architect who designed it quit the project before it was completed and never saw the finished building in person

name: Angkor Wat
clues: I'm the largest religious monument in the world
I was originally constructed as a Hindu temple, later becoming Buddhist
I appear on my country's national flag
funFacts: Angkor Wat is aligned with the spring equinox so that the sun rises directly over the central tower
The temple complex was 'lost' for centuries, covered by jungle until French explorers rediscovered it in the 1840s
The sandstone blocks used in construction were quarried more than 50km away and transported to the site

name: Christ the Redeemer
clues: I stand with arms outstretched over a major city
I'm made of reinforced concrete and soapstone
I was completed in 1931 after 9 years of construction
funFacts: The statue is struck by lightning several times a year, requiring constant repairs
The original design called for Christ holding a globe in one hand and a cross in the other
The statue weighs 635 tons and is 98 feet tall, not including its 26-foot pedestal
